awd_titl_txt: SpecEES: Intelligent Energy Efficient Spectrum Access for Wireless IoT
awd_abstract_narration:
The future Internet of Things (IoT) will support numerous types of applications producing overwhelming data traffic with highly different Quality-of-Service (QoS) requirements, creating challenges in terms of spectrum scarcity, and prohibitive energy consumption of billions of devices. Cognitive radio (CR) is a promising technology for IoT not only because of its dynamic spectrum access capability, but also due to its potential of providing diverse QoS and energy efficiencies by delivering different types of traffic using different bands. Although dynamic spectrum access to multiple bands can bring various benefits to the IoT, it also introduces significant challenges. This research offers transformative advances in overall network energy efficiencies, by leveraging order-of-magnitude energy efficiencies of low-frequency bands, novel heterogeneous battery management, and spectrum access methods designed to take advantage of these two new advances. This research is truly interdisciplinary covering integrating advances in circuits/hardware design, device battery management, and synergistic energy-efficient networking and spectrum access.  This research will generate innovative techniques to serve numerous applications of IoT technologies, e.g., smart cities and smart homes, mobile health, and intelligent transportation systems. It will also greatly advance the understanding of energy efficiency of IoT devices and networks.
 
The research objective of this proposal is to design, analyze, and evaluate transformative intelligent energy-efficient spectrum access technologies for wireless IoT. This research is the first to systematically address the energy efficiency issue in wireless IoT spectrum access through intelligent battery system management of IoT devices and innovative wideband enhancement for electrically-small antennas to unlock order-of-magnitude energy efficiencies of low- frequency bands, and where new intelligent energy-efficient channel rendezvous algorithms are designed to leverage these advantages for IoT spectrum access. The proposed project consists of three main research thrusts: (1) energy-efficient channel rendezvous for enhanced spectrum access with adaptive power management; (2) cognitive battery system to maximize the energy efficiency of each IoT device by optimally integrating heterogeneous batteries in each device and dynamically matching the power consumption and battery characteristics; and (3) digital non-Foster methods to unlock energy efficiencies of low-frequency bands. This project also integrates research findings into related undergraduate and graduate courses and diversity support.

por.por_cntn:
Future Internet of Things (IoT) will support numerous types of applications producing overwhelming data traffic with highly different Quality-of-Service (QoS) requirements, which also creates challenges in terms of spectrum scarcity. Dynamic spectrum access is a promising technology for IoT due to its potential of providing diverse QoS by delivering different types of traffic using different bands. Although dynamic spectrum access to multiple bands can bring various benefits to the IoT, it also introduces significant challenges.

The research objective of this project is to design, analyze, and evaluate innovative intelligent energy-efficient spectrum access technologies for wireless IoT. One unique feature of this research is the potential for greatly enhanced energy efficiency by leveraging breakthroughs in optimized inhomogeneous battery management, novel digital non-Foster circuits to enable the use of energy-efficient low frequency bands, and synergistically designed spectrum access to maximize overall energy efficiency.

This research systematically addresses the energy efficiency issue in wireless IoT spectrum access through intelligent battery system management of IoT devices and innovative wideband enhancement for electrically-small antennas to unlock order-of-magnitude energy efficiencies of low-frequency bands, and leveraging them in designing intelligent energy-efficient spectrum access algorithms for IoT. This project consists of three main research thrusts: 1) energy-efficient spectrum access with adaptive power management; 2) cognitive battery system to maximize the energy efficiency of each IoT device by optimally integrating heterogeneous batteries in each device and dynamically matching the power consumption and battery characteristics; and 3) digital non-Foster methods to unlock energy efficiencies of low-frequency bands.

This research offers transformative advances in overall network energy efficiencies, when the order-of-magnitude energy efficiencies of low-frequency non-Foster methods are further combined with novel battery management and with spectrum access methods designed to leverage these new advances. It provides innovative techniques to numerous applications of IoT technologies, e.g., smart cities and smart homes, mobile health, and intelligent transportation systems, and emerging technologies with dynamic spectrum access, e.g., public safety networks and emergency networks. It also greatly advances the understanding of energy efficiency of IoT devices. As an unexpected offshoot of the digital non-Foster antenna research, the fundamental physics of the Wheeler-Chu limit for the Q (quality factor) of gravitational-wave radiation was discovered.

This project provided excellent opportunities for graduate and undergraduate research students to gain valuable educational training and research experiences. Three PhD students and four REU (Research Experiences for Undergraduates) students have participated in this research. Results from this research are presented at IEEE journals and international conferences. Topics on IoT, battery management, and digital non-Foster systems with ample inputs from the research work are incorporated into the graduate-level courses taught at UNC Charlotte. The synergy between the topics covered in the courses and the research results in this project mutually benefits both. The PIs also worked closely with various programs encouraging students from under-represented groups to participate in research activities.
